title: Which team will win the 2020 College Football Playoff national championship?
preds: Adding LSU relative home field advantage with game in NO. Thanks for adding that fact @bayesianchimp
In the stars, but my forcasting is good.

Refined my stochastic model to add in a relative 'home field advantage' for LSU, given that this will be played NO which is very close to home for them.  Doesn't change my results much using 10,000 monte carlo draws from poisson point generators.

Coming at this a bit late.  I used the last three games for each team to estimate the points for and against for each, adjusted by their respective standings in the Big12 + Big 10 + PAC 12, etc conferences.  I then used 1000 Poisson Monte Carlo draws to simulate the respective potential scores for LSU vs Clemson and the resulting spread.  Summing up the total wins favors LSU over Clemson 1.3:1.  Will be interesting to see the results as college football is supposed to be more volatile than professional.
Forecast moved closer to the 'crowd' right now..  https://nypost.com/2020/01/04/burrow-lsu-blowing-away-betting-public-for-title-game/
Clemson showed some vulnerabilities in the OSU game. LSU is solid in all phases. Both have fantastic Quarterbacks but this is like a home game for LSU.

Subjective evaluation of the matchups: LSU-Oklahoma is 67:33
OSU-Clemson is 60:40.
LSU-Ohio State is 45:55.
LSU-Clemson is 55:45.
Oklahoma-Ohio State is 30:70.
Oklahoma-Clemson is 40:60. Conjoint probability:
Clemson: .40*((.67*.45)+(.33*.60)) = 19.98%
LSU:  .67*((.40*.55)+(.60*.45)) = 32.83%
Ohio State:  .60*((.67*.55)+(.33*.70)) = 35.97%
Oklahoma:  .33*((.60*.30)+(.40*.40)) = 11.22%
Looks like i'm not the only Sooner to have their heart broke one time to many by their dismal playoff record.
based on who wins the semifinal games and best chance to earn at least 50% to win title.

Updating my forecast to reflect the recent suspensions of 3 OU players.  Dopped Oklahoma down to 5% and increased the odds down the line for the other teams. https://www.tulsaworld.com/sports/college/ou/ou-football-reports-say-three-sooners-players-suspended-for-peach/article_6ed79a95-159c-5748-ba2b-c1384d04c377.html

Any given Saturday ... this is a complicated forecast due to the number of human factors involved in the outcome - players, coaches, referees, nutritionists, forecaster bias... Some factors that may give insight include shared opponents, strength and weakness within matchups, etc.   Considering the OSU-Clemson matchup first - Scoring Offense and Scoring Defense statistics are a virtual dead heat.  OSU is 2.2 pts per game higher on Scoring O, Clemson has 1.9 pts per game lower on Scoring D.  There is a potential argument to be made regarding the quality of the opponents in this game with OSU playing teams that were ranked 8, 8, 13, 13, and 25 at the time of the game while Clemson's wins against ranked teams were against 12 early in the season and 23 at the end.  Intangibles in this game will be key and thus fairly difficult to predict.  Individual matchups and day of performances will be the deciding factor.  No shared opponents to help here - This game goes to OSU but only 60% to 40%. On the LSU, OKL side - the statistics and pundits all seem to point toward LSU.  LSU's scoring Offense statistics are 4 pts high than OKL and scoring defense is also 3.3 pts lower.  The LSU statistics were also accumulated against higher quality competition: 9, 7, 9, 3, 4 vs. 11, 13, 21, 7.  Both teams played and beat Texas by a touchdown in the first half of the season, so no real indicators there. I would give LSU the large edge in this one 90% to 10%.   Following the matchups this puts OSU against LSU in the final.  OSU's scoring Offense is only slightly higher than LSU, but defensively there is a wide gap of 8.7 pts.  Again, no shared opponents to help with this.  The quality of competition edge tilts toward LSU here and they get the nod 60% to 40%.
this prediction based in its  entirety on interviews with player parole officers....(not really)
